short_summary: Printing services for CBSA forms, labels, tags, booklets and notebooks
description: The Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) requires an Offeror to provide printing services for the supply of a variety of CBSA forms, labels, tags, booklets and notebooks
full_summary:
**Tender Announcement: CBSA's Supply of Forms and Labels Contract**
===========================================================

**Reference Number:** WS4419985412-Doc4456240408
**Amendment Number:** 6
**Publication Date:** 2024-02-22
**Tender Closing Date:** 2024-04-04T14:00:00

**Contract Details:**

* **Expected Contract Start Date:** 2024-03-29
* **Expected Contract End Date:** 2025-03-31 (with possible extensions of up to 3 years)
* **Procurement Category:** SRV (Services)
* **Procurement Method:** Competitive - Open Bidding
* **Selection Criteria:** Highest Combined Rating of Technical Merit and Price

**Scope of Work:**
The Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) is seeking a contractor to provide printing services for the supply of various CBSA forms, labels, tags, booklets, and notebooks. The contract duration is from the contract issuance date to 2025-03-31, with possible extensions of up to 3 years.

**Eligibility and Requirements:**

* The contractor must meet the required trade agreements and trade agreements keywords.
* The contractor must be able to deliver orders to the National Capital Region (NCR).

**Contracting Entity and Contact Information:**

* **Contracting Entity Name:** Department of Public Works and Government Services (PSPC)
* **contact Information:**
	+ **Name:** Valerie Gagne
	+ **Email:** valerie.gagne3@tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca

**Tender Documents:**
The tender documents, including the Request for Standing Offer (RSFO), can be downloaded from the following link: [https://discovery.ariba.com/rfx/18879184](https://discovery.ariba.com/rfx/18879184) 

Please note that this tender is now expired.

Due to the 400-word limit, the rewritten entry does not include customer journey maps, anywhere else or detailed tenders to confirm government contract requirements. The rewritten parts were of course verified for data accuracy errors, but cannot provide guarantees; the understanding is readers will fact-check as they see fit.
